questions.text:
Which of the following is a component of RMNCH+A strategy?
Adolescent health
Family planning
Geriatric health
Maternal and Child health
Newborn Health
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The RMNCH+A strategy is a comprehensive approach launched by the Government of India to integrate interventions across the life cycle. The acronym stands for:

  • R - Reproductive health
  • M - Maternal health
  • N - Newborn health
  • C - Child health
  • +A - Adolescent health

Family Planning is a core component under Reproductive health. Geriatric health is not a part of this specific strategy, which focuses on the reproductive, maternal, newborn, child, and adolescent age groups. (Option A and D ruled out)

  • The strategy formally recognizes adolescence as a distinct phase of life. It integrates maternal and child health initiatives with broader reproductive health services, which include family planning, adolescent health programs, HIV care, gender-related services, and the management of preconception and prenatal diagnostic techniques. Furthermore, the approach strengthens the connection between home- and community-based care and clinical services provided in health facilities. It emphasizes the establishment of robust linkages, referrals, and counter-referrals across all tiers of the healthcare system. This creates a seamless, continuous pathway of care, thereby generating a synergistic effect that enhances overall health outcomes and impact.

Related important points and concepts:

  • The "+A" for Adolescent health was added to the earlier RCH (Reproductive and Child Health) program to emphasize the importance of this age group.
  • The strategy aims to reduce maternal and infant mortality and address the unmet needs for contraception and reproductive health.

Key Takeaways:

  • RMNCH+A covers Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn, Child, and Adolescent health.
  • Geriatric health is not included in this framework.

Explanation:

  • Mean and Median are measures of Central Tendency, not Dispersion. Measures of dispersion describe how spread out the data is (e.g., range, variance, standard deviation). This is the incorrect combination.
  • Standard error is a measure of the variability or precision of a sample statistic (like the sample mean) from the population parameter. (Option A ruled out)
  • The coefficient of correlation (e.g., Pearson's r) quantifies the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables. (Option B ruled out)
  • Skewness is a measure of the asymmetry of a probability distribution. (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Mean, median, and mode are measures of Central Tendency.
  • Range, variance, and standard deviation are measures of Dispersion.

questions.text: Quartiles and tertiles are measures of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Quartiles (dividing data into four equal parts: Q1, Q2, Q3) and tertiles (dividing data into three equal parts) are positional measures or measures of location. They describe the position of a value within a dataset but are not measures of central tendency (which identify the center) or dispersion (which describe spread). (Options A,D ,B ruled out)
  • Q2 (the second quartile) is the same as the median, a measure of central tendency, but quartiles/tertiles as a group are classified as locational measures.

Key Takeaways:

  • Quartiles and tertiles are measures of location, describing specific points in a data set.

questions.text:
Organize the following steps in the correct sequence for conducting research:
Conduct data analysis
Selecting population
Setting research question
Setting research objective
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The logical sequence of research steps is:

  1. Setting research question : Identifying the broad problem area.
  2. Setting research objective : Defining specific, measurable goals based on the research question.
  3. Selecting population : Choosing the target population and sample after knowing what to study.
  4. Conduct data analysis : Analyzing the collected data is one of the final steps.

Key Takeaways:

  • The research process begins with defining a question and objectives before any data collection or analysis.

questions.text: In a specific population of a town, 6000 were below the age of 15 years and there were 2000 above the age of 65 years. A total of 12,000 were earning members in the town. Calculate the dependency ratio.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Dependency Ratio is calculated as the ratio of the economically dependent population (those too young or too old to work) to the economically productive population.

  • Formula: Dependency Ratio = (Number of dependents (Age <15 + Age >65)) / (Number of economically productive population (15-64 years))
  • Given:
    • Dependent Population (0-14 + 65+) = 6000 + 2000 = 8000
    • Economically Productive Population = 12,000
  • Calculation: Dependency Ratio = 8000 / 12000 = 666 ≈ 0.66 (Option A, B and D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Dependency Ratio = (Population <15 + Population >65) / (Population 15-64)

questions.text: In a village having 100 children, 10 developed measles the previous year. Now, this year, 20 children developed measles for the first time. What is the incidence rate of measles?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Incidence rate is the number of new cases of a disease that occur in a population at risk during a specified time period.
  • The population at risk are those who can develop the disease. The 10 children who had measles last year are no longer at risk (they are immune). Therefore, the population at risk at the start of this year is 100 - 10 = 90 children.
  • Number of new cases this year = 20
  • Incidence Rate = (Number of new cases / Population at risk) × 100 = (20 / 90) × 100 ≈ 22% (Option A,B and D are ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Incidence measures new cases in a population at risk over a time period.

choices.text: Men who have sex with men (MSM)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a high-risk group for HIV?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • High-risk groups, also known as core groups or bridge populations, are those with a significantly higher prevalence of HIV and who can act as a bridge to transmit the infection to the general population.
  • Injecting Drug Users (IDU), Men who have Sex with Men (MSM), and Commercial Sex Workers (CSW) are classic, universally recognized core high-risk groups due to specific high-risk behaviors.
  • Long Distance Truck Drivers (LDTD) are considered a vulnerable group or a risk group, but not a core high-risk group. Their risk is behavioral (e.g., contact with CSWs) and situational (mobility), but they are not defined by the same level of intrinsic high-risk activity as the core groups. They are a priority group for intervention because they can spread infection geographically, but they are not classified alongside the core groups.

Key Takeaways:

  • Core high-risk groups for HIV include IDU, MSM, and CSW.
  • LDTD are a vulnerable group, not a core group.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs are used for clinical cure of malaria?
1. Artemether
2. Sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine
3. Chloroquine
4. Primaquine
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Clinical cure refers to the treatment that clears the parasite burden from the blood, relieving the acute symptoms of malaria. This is achieved by schizonticidal drugs.
  • Artemether (an artemisinin derivative), Sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (a sulfa drug combination), and Chloroquine are all blood schizonticides and are used for clinical cure.
  • Primaquine is a tissue schizonticide (acts on hypnozoites in the liver for P. vivax and P. ovale) and a gametocidal It is not used for clinical cure of the acute attack but for radical cure (preventing relapse) and preventing transmission.

Key Takeaways:

  • Blood schizonticides (e.g., Chloroquine, Artemisinin, SP) are for clinical cure.
  • Primaquine is for radical cure and gametocidal action.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true?
A) Widal test is positive in first week of illness
B) Microscopic agglutination test (MAT) is gold standard in leptospirosis
C) The Weil-Felix test is used in typhus fever
D) Standard agglutination test is used in Brucellosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Microscopic agglutination test (MAT) is gold standard in leptospirosis: MAT is the reference standard serological test for confirming leptospirosis. (Statement B)
  • The Weil-Felix test is used in typhus fever: The Weil-Felix test is an agglutination test based on cross-reactivity between Rickettsia antigens and Proteus antigens and is used for diagnosing typhus fever. (Statement B) (Option D ruled out)
  • Standard agglutination test is used in Brucellosis: The Serum Agglutination Test (SAT), also known as the Standard Agglutination Test or Wright's test, is the primary serological test used for diagnosing brucellosis. (Statement D)
  • Widal test is positive in first week of illness: this is a false statement. Antibodies for the Widal test (for enteric fever) typically appear by the end of the first week and peak during the third week. A positive test in the first week is uncommon and not diagnostic. (Option A and C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Widal test becomes positive after the first week of typhoid fever.
  • MAT is the gold standard for leptospirosis.
  • Weil-Felix test is for rickettsial diseases (typhus group).
  • Standard agglutination test (SAT) is for brucellosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old sexually active male presents to the UHC with complaints of painful urination and a thick yellow urethral discharge for the past 3 days. He denies any fever, chills, or flank pain. He reports multiple unprotected sexual encounters in the past month. A urethral swab sent for Gram staining, shows intracellular gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes. The organism is resistant to penicillin. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The history (sexually active, urethral discharge, dysuria) and Gram stain findings (intracellular gram-negative diplococci) are classic for gonococcal urethritis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • The key phrase is "The organism is resistant to penicillin." This indicates Penicillinase-Producing Neisseria gonorrhoeae (PPNG), making penicillin and amoxicillin ineffective.
  • The first-line treatment for uncomplicated gonorrhea, especially with known or suspected resistance, is a third-generation cephalosporin, specifically Ceftriaxone (250 mg IM as a single dose). Dual therapy with Azithromycin (for possible co-existing Chlamydia) is often recommended but not listed in the options. Ceftriaxone alone is the correct choice from the given options.

Explanation of other options:

Vancomycin (Option B) : Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic used for Gram-positive infections (e.g., MRSA). It has no activity against Gram-negative diplococci like N. gonorrhoeae.

Amoxicillin (Option C) : The question explicitly states the organism is resistant to penicillin. Amoxicillin, a penicillin-class drug, would be ineffective.

Tetracycline (Option D): While tetracyclines like doxycycline can be used for Chlamydia, they are not recommended as monotherapy for gonorrhea due to high levels of resistance.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ceftriaxone is the drug of choice for gonorrhea, especially with penicillin resistance.
  • Intracellular gram-negative diplococci on Gram stain are diagnostic for gonorrhea.

questions.text: You are a medical officer at a PHC collecting data for disease burden. You divide those with diseases into mild, moderate and severe groups. Then few are selected from each group for the study. This is which type of sampling?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Stratified random sampling involves dividing the population into homogeneous subgroups called strata (in this case, disease severity: mild, moderate, severe) and then selecting a random sample from each of these strata.
  • This technique ensures that all segments of the population (all severity levels) are adequately represented in the sample, which is the described scenario.

Explanation of other options:

Simple random sampling (Option A): This involves selecting subjects entirely by chance from the whole population without creating any subgroups first.

Systematic random sampling (Option B): This involves selecting subjects at a regular interval (e.g., every 5th patient) from a list of the entire population.

Simple sampling (Option D): This is not a standard term in research methodology.

Key Takeaways:

  • Stratified sampling is used when the population has distinct subgroups (strata) and the researcher wants to ensure representation from each subgroup.

choices.text: To reduce number of health workers
To get early information of outbreaks of diarrhoea, respiratory infections

questions.text: In the Maha Kumbh Mela, what was the purpose of mobile medical vans?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The primary function of mobile medical vans or units in mass gatherings like the Kumbh Mela is sentinel surveillance.
  • They are strategically placed to act as the first point of contact for a large number of attendees. By treating common ailments and collecting data on presenting symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, fever, respiratory issues), they serve as an early warning system to detect potential disease outbreaks before they can spread widely through the massive population.

Explanation of other options:

To reduce number of health workers (Option A): The vans are an additional resource, not a replacement for fixed facilities or health workers.

For immediate quarantine measures (Option B) :While they might identify cases needing quarantine, their main role is detection and initial treatment, not housing patients for isolation.

To diagnose with lab tests (Option D): Mobile vans typically provide basic point-of-care testing. Advanced lab diagnosis is done at designated fixed facilities.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mobile medical vans in mass gatherings are crucial for early detection and surveillance of communicable diseases.

choices.text: Within first 7 days of menstrual cycle
Within 7 days of next menstrual cycle

questions.text: The best timing of CuT 380A insertion to ensure good compliance under the RCH program are all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The CuT 380A IUD can be inserted at various times to maximize compliance:
    • A) Within 48 hours of delivery and B) Immediate post-partum are correct timings for postpartum insertion.
    • C) Within first 7 days of menstrual cycle is correct. Insertion during menses ensures the woman is not pregnant and the cervix is slightly dilated, making insertion easier.
  • Within 7 days of next menstrual cycle is incorrect and illogical. If the insertion is planned for a future cycle, it relies on the patient returning, which reduces compliance. The standard guideline is insertion within 7 days of the onset of menstruation (i.e., the current cycle), not the next one.

Key Takeaways:

  • IUD can be inserted post-placental delivery, within 48 hrs postpartum, during menstruation, or anytime if reasonably sure the woman is not pregnant.
  • "Within 7 days of next menstrual cycle" is not a standard or practical recommendation.

questions.text: In a group of patients with diabetes, their weights were compared before and after nutritional counselling. Statistical test of significance to be used is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A paired t-test is used to compare the means of two related groups or paired measurements taken from the same subjects at two different times (e.g., before and after an intervention like nutritional counselling).
  • In this case, the same group of diabetic patients is being measured twice (before and after counselling), making the data "paired" or "dependent."

Explanation of other options:

ANOVA (Option A): Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) is used to compare the means of more than two independent groups.

Chi-square test (Option B): The Chi-square test is used to compare categorical data (e.g., proportions, frequencies), not continuous data like weight.

Unpaired t-test (Option D): An unpaired t-test (or independent samples t-test) is used to compare the means of two different, independent groups (e.g., weights of a group receiving counselling vs. a group not receiving counselling).

Key Takeaways:

  • Paired t-test is for comparing the same group at two different times (before/after studies).

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents to a Health & Wellness Centre for a routine check-up. His blood pressure readings on two separate visits are 148/90 mmHg. He is asymptomatic, has no diabetes, renal disease, or cardiovascular history. According to the Ayushman Aarogya Mandir guidelines, which of the following is the most appropriate first-line drug and dose for initiating treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has Stage 1 Hypertension (BP 140-159/90-99 mmHg) without any compelling indications (e.g., diabetes, CKD, heart failure) or comorbidities.
  • As per the Ayushman Bharat - Health and Wellness Centre (AB-HWC) protocol and consensus Indian guidelines (like those from the API), the recommended first-line antihypertensive for most patients is a Calcium Channel Blocker (CCB) or a Thiazide diuretic.
  • Amlodipine 5 mg OD is a standard, well-tolerated, first-line CCB dose.
  • The other options are incorrect due to incorrect dosing or drug class priority:
    • Telmisartan 80 mg: ARBs like Telmisartan are also first-line, but the starting dose is typically 40 mg, not 80 mg. (Option B ruled out)
    • Hydrochlorothiazide 50 mg: The standard starting dose for HCTZ is 5 mg - 25 mg. 50 mg is a high dose not used for initiation due to increased risk of metabolic side effects. (Option C ruled out)
    • Metoprolol 100 mg BD: Beta-blockers like Metoprolol are not preferred as first-line therapy for uncomplicated hypertension according to most contemporary guidelines due to inferior outcomes compared to CCBs/ARBs/Thiazides. The starting dose is also high (25-50 mg OD is typical). (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • For uncomplicated Stage 1 HTN, Amlodipine 5 mg OD is a standard first-line choice in Indian primary care settings.
  • Always check for correct drug and appropriate starting dose.

References: Ayushman Bharat - Health and Wellness Centre (AB-HWC) Clinical Treatment Guidelines; Indian Hypertension Guidelines (ISH/API).

questions.text: Gene pool term is used for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The gene pool is a fundamental concept in population genetics. (Option B,C and D ruled out)
  • It is defined as the total sum of all genes and their alleles present in an interbreeding population at a given time.
  • It represents the complete set of genetic information available to be passed on to the next generation within that population. This term is not used for an individual, family, or community.

Key Takeaways:

  • The gene pool is the aggregate of all alleles in a population.
